listing.name: GitHub
listing.description:
The GitHub Power-Up for Trello let’s teams track everything that’s going on in GitHub directly from their Trello boards.  Bring perspective to your codebase by attaching pull requests, issues, branches, and more directly to their respective cards.  In a glance, see whether a PR has been merged, the status of checks, who’s assigned to a PR, and more. Checks will also display as visual badges on the front of cards color coded to their status.

- Attach branches, commits, issues and pull requests directly to cards.
- See the status of pull requests on the front of cards.
- Identify cards that have not passed their checks with color coded badges that display on the front of cards.
- Developers and managers can easily jump into GitHub to work on assigned tasks in a single click.
- Associate one or more GitHub repositories with a board.
- The GitHub Power-Up supports both GitHub and GitHub Enterprise instances.

![screenshot](https://github.trello.services/images/screenshots/GitHub_1.jpg)
![screenshot](https://github.trello.services/images/screenshots/GitHub_2.jpg)
![screenshot](https://github.trello.services/images/screenshots/GitHub_3.jpg)

- plain old string interpolation

card.name: PaC Spike: Flow 1 - Find material in repo

data.text:
Here are my thoughts from Slack: https://twstudios.slack.com/archives/CHCEGDBSA/p1559071056009300?thread_ts=1558719804.003000&cid=CHCEGDBSA

- Prefer to not have: “Includes pipeline config”. A magical user experience is that it is found automatically. How about:
 1. They enter a material URL.
 2. We try to clone it and find out and show a message: “We found a pipeline config in your repo. Do you want us to use that ... ?”
 3. If not, and it takes more than 5 seconds or is too big a repo for us to shallow clone from, then we show a message: “We couldn’t clone the repo, do you have a pipeline config that you’d like us to use?”

- When in the “Add config repo (inferring details) parse config” part, it would be good to show progress to a user.

/cc @steven_st

card.desc:
The pipeline config API may report errors on specific attributes that may not be possible to cover with client-side validations.

Examples:

- Duplicate pipeline name
- Destination directory outside of pipeline workspace

When errors are returned, we should bind them in context to the attributes on the model and associated nested models.

Otherwise the user will not know what errors to fix and will not be able to continue in the flow.

This work is partly complete, but needs finishing.

Looked into this a bit - at the surface, seems straightforward.

First rock I tripped over: group permissions. The dashboard api needs permissions for each group and that is calculated from it child pipelines. I believe this is a solved problem though - choosing a sensible set of permissions based on more top-level configs. We seem to do this in part already in other places

Stand up CloudFront instance for downloads. Please read description for details.
card.desc:
We need a CF instance to cache S3 downloads per region. However, it is important to set the correct caching behaviors:

1. Installer binaries: cache these forever
2. Metadata (`latest.json`, `stable.json`) - either don't cache at all, or set the max-age to be very small (e.g., 5 min); otherwise, we can't promote new installers.

listing.overview: Add custom fields like text, numbers, checkboxes, dates, and dropdown lists to your cards.
listing.description:
Custom data fields for Trello cards.

Ever want to add a dropdown menu, checkbox, or additional date fields to Trello cards? The Custom Fields Power-Up let’s you do all that and more, bringing process and formality to your workflow to meet your team’s unique needs. Whether it’s number fields to track feature requests, additional date fields for start and end dates of marketing campaigns, dropdown menus of SKUs to manage orders from customers, and more, Custom Fields has you covered. Plus, field data is surfaced to the front of Trello cards for information in a glance.

- Custom fields for text, numbers, checkboxes, dates, and dropdown lists.
- Display field data as card badges on the front of cards.
- Field names support emoji for extra visual appeal.
- Custom Fields are supported on mobile devices.
- Export Custom Fields data in JSON and CSV board exports. *Note: CSV exports are only available on Business Class and Enterprise teams.*

![screenshot](https://card-fields.trello.services/images/custom-fields-1.jpg)

cards.desc:
Given a valid material config, evaluate feasibility and difficulties of detecting definition files for installed PaC plugins.

The spike is located here: https://github.com/ibnc/gocd/tree/pac_mat_spike

Considerations:

- Ask plugin for effective file patterns?
- What to do when multiple plugin patterns match? (e.g., `*.gocd.yaml` and `*.gocd.json`)

Questions:
- ~~What if the repo/material is already being used as a pac?~~
- Do we scan automatically, or have a scan button? It's possible to create config repos where the repo has no config files in it
- What should an "OK" response look like? What about the response when no config files are found? what about an error?
cards.name: Spike - PaC detect definition/configuration files from a material.

cards.desc:
The pipeline config API may report errors on specific attributes that may not be possible to cover with client-side validations.

Examples:

- Duplicate pipeline name
- Destination directory outside of pipeline workspace

When errors are returned, we should bind them in context to the attributes on the model and associated nested models.

Otherwise the user will not know what errors to fix and will not be able to continue in the flow.

This work is partly complete, but needs finishing.

cards.desc:
We need a CF instance to cache S3 downloads per region. However, it is important to set the correct caching behaviors:

1. Installer binaries: cache these forever
2. Metadata (`latest.json`, `stable.json`) - either don't cache at all, or set the max-age to be very small (e.g., 5 min); otherwise, we can't promote new installers.
